message: Hi guys, I'm currently learning puppet via a Vagrant configuration but I'm also stuck with my pip requirements. Is there a solution to not put each requirements in separate "package" section and simply run the file which contains all requirements?
But it seems to exist several projects or web pages explaining out to us (can't find them at the moment but i read it...)
Not sure if Puppet is the right tool to handle virtualenv/pip installations
puppet macro to run a requirements files: https://github.com/theteam/vagrant-django-template/blob/master/modules/python2/manifests/venv/setup.pp
I'm currently running my requirements in fabric (simplier) and puppet keeps only my packages up-to-date :)

I have found the article i was thinking about http://journal.uggedal.com/deploying-wsgi-applications-with-puppet It don't talk about pip, but it gives an example of Puppet used to manage WSGI applications. Not sure if i like this solution but it can be good/useful...

yes, that's what i do, i finally decide the frontier between Puppet and Fabric was there (see https://convore.com/puppet/where-is-the-frontier-between-a-system-integration-tool-like-puppetchef-and-an-application-deployment-one-like-fabriccapistrano/)
Puppet 2.7.0 supports PIP and Virtualenv via a package type provider (http://projects.puppetlabs.com/issues/6527).
